Patients with oppositional defiant disorder display argumentative, angry behavior towards authority figures and tend to blame others for their transgressions (e.g., the mayor). However, vandalism and theft/deceitful conduct are not typical features of oppositional defiant disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with intermittent explosive disorder have recurrent outbursts of physical/verbal aggression. However, theft/deceitful conduct and vandalism are not features of intermittent explosive disorder. Moreover, intermittent explosive disorder cannot be diagnosed if the criteria for another disorder associated with physical aggression have been met.

C) INCORRECT:

Because patients with narcissistic personality disorder have an exaggerated sense of self-importance, they might consider work boring or beneath them. However, vandalism, theft/deceitful conduct, and physical aggression are not typical features of narcissistic personality disorder. Instead, patients have fantasies of unlimited success, power, and/or wealth, as well as a pathological need for praise.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with conduct disorder have a history of rule violation, theft/deceitful conduct, and/or physical/verbal aggression beginning during childhood or adolescence. While the diagnosis of conduct disorder is more common in male individuals, it cannot be diagnosed in an individual over the age of 18 years once the criteria for a related disorder have been met.

E) CORRECT:

A history of expulsion from school at the age of 12 years for destroying school property and threatening to assault classmates is highly suggestive of conduct disorder. Antisocial personality disorder can be diagnosed if an adult (18 years of age or older) has a history of conduct disorder that manifested before the age of 15 years and has met ≥ 3 of the following 7 criteria after the age of 15 years: repeatedly engaging in activities that are grounds for arrest; deceitfulness; impulsivity/failure to plan ahead; a history of repeated aggression; reckless disregard for one's own safety or the safety of others; a failure to fulfill work-related or financial obligations; and/or a lack of remorse or emotional indifference to the plight of others. This patient has, in some way, shape, or form, met all 7 criteria.

See “Overview of cluster B personality disorders” table.
questions.hint: Upon questioning what he thinks about other people living in his town, the patient responds “Hate, hate, hate. Hate, hate, hate. Double hate. LOATHE ENTIRELY!”

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. She feels well and has no history of serious illness. She reports that she has been married for 2 years and has argued with her husband a lot during the past 6 months because she suspects that he is cheating on her. She hasn't spoken to her sister in 4 years because her sister “always humiliates me in front of others.” She gets along well with her friends but does not talk to them about her problems because she is afraid that they will gossip about her behind her back. She works as a teacher at an elementary school. She has been monogamous with her husband for the entire marriage except for a sexual relationship with a colleague 13 months ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she has a stable mood and a neutral affect. Her thought process is goal-directed and thought content focuses on possible negative eventualities, but she demonstrates intact reality testing. Her speech is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by excessive suspicion and pervasive distrust of others, while psychotic symptoms are absent. Individuals with paranoid personality disorder often present with suspicions of infidelity, unjustified fear that others will use information against them, and disproportionate reactions to perceived attacks. Consequently, individuals with paranoid personality disorder tend to be emotionally isolated and unable to form close interpersonal relationships (See “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table).

Most patients with personality disorders consider their symptoms normal; these egosyntonic behavioral traits lead to significant distress and impaired social functioning. Personality disorders typically begin in early adulthood and remain stable over time. Treatment is challenging and usually includes psychotherapy. Symptomatic treatment may be helpful in patients with comorbid traits (e.g., symptoms of anxiety, psychosis).

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with schizoid personality disorder may be unable to form close interpersonal relationships and find it difficult to trust others. However, schizoid personality disorder typically also manifests with little interest in sexual relationships and a preference for solitary activities, and mental status examination may show flattened affect.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with avoidant personality disorder refrain from interpersonal contact because of a preoccupation with, and hypersensitivity to, criticism. However, in avoidant personality disorder, the lack of interpersonal contact results from feelings of inadequacy, low self-esteem, and risk avoidance rather than distrust of others.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder may be suspicious and distrustful of others and often lack close friends. However, schizotypal personality disorder typically also manifests with eccentric behavior (e.g., bizarre speech) or physical appearance, magical thinking, unusual perceptual experiences (e.g., body illusions), and/or constricted affect, none of which is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with borderline personality disorder (BPD) may be suspicious of others, have unstable personal relationships, and fear abandonment. However, this patient's behavior is more severe than that expected in BPD. In addition, the patient does not display the self-damaging behavior and impulsivity that is characteristic of BPD.

F) INCORRECT:

Individuals with delusional disorder may have an exaggerated distrust of others and insist that they are being cheated on, conspired against, and/or harassed. However, delusional disorder also manifests with at least one type of delusion (e.g., jealous, erotomanic, grandiose) and associated clinical features. While individuals with delusional disorder may show impaired reality testing and/or abnormalities of thought content regarding the delusional belief, functioning unrelated to the belief is typically normal.
questions.hint: Projection is a defense mechanism often seen in individuals with this condition.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with borderline personality disorder comes to the psychiatrist for a follow-up examination. Two months ago, she started treatment with fluoxetine because of persistent feelings of emptiness and self-injurious behavior. She has been receiving dialectical behavior therapy from a clinical psychologist for the past year. Before the initiation of pharmacotherapy, the psychiatrist and psychologist met face-to-face to exchange clinical information and establish mutual treatment goals. The patient agreed to the treatment plan, which included both pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy. The patient reports that she stopped going to psychotherapy for 2 weeks because the psychologist is a "traitor" who manipulates her emotions. The patient says that she only trusts the psychiatrist, who she describes as “my personal hero,” and wants to continue pharmacotherapy. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?

choices.text: "I will discuss this with your psychologist and let you know our decision."
"Quitting psychotherapy is only possible if we increase your visits to this practice.”
“It would make sense for you to choose a different psychologist."
"When setting your treatment goals, you agreed to attend sessions with your psychologist."
"If this is your decision, we can pause psychotherapy for 3 months"

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Providers may share relevant patient information (except for psychotherapy notes and substance use disorder treatment records) without a waiver of confidentiality. However, making a treatment plan without involving the patient in the decision-making process is inappropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

This statement is inappropriate because it encourages splitting and does not involve all members of the multiple-provider team in decision-making. Additionally, pharmacotherapy plays a complementary role, while psychotherapy (e.g., dialectical behavioral therapy) is the first-line treatment for patients with BPD.

C) INCORRECT:

Because splitting (psychiatry) endangers adherence, changes in the treatment plan may be necessary. However, this statement is inappropriate because it encourages splitting, and changing providers may be counterproductive at this time.

D) CORRECT:

Treatment for BPD can be challenging because patients may project their feelings onto their providers (e.g., fear of abandonment) or respond to therapy with psychological defense mechanisms. Although a patient always has the right to choose a different provider or to opt out of treatment entirely, they should be encouraged to adhere to the existing treatment plan. In a multiple-provider setting, providers can support each other when patients are resistant to treatment.

In this scenario, the psychiatrist should remind the patient of the treatment goals and encourage adherence to therapy. All providers involved in patient care should collaborate toward common treatment goals (e.g., emotional stability, improved relationships). Regular communication, clarification of roles, and plans for crisis management (e.g., whom to call in case of an emergency) are necessary in a multiple-provider setting.

E) INCORRECT:

This statement is inappropriate because it encourages splitting. Providers should collaborate with each other and work as a team towards mutual treatment goals. In addition, all members of a multiple-provider team should be involved in making decisions.
questions.hint: The patient idealizes her psychiatrist and distrusts her psychologist. This defense mechanism, referred to as splitting, is characteristic of borderline personality disorder (BPD).

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents after an argument with his wife. He reports that his mood was fine until she told him that she was going to dinner with some friends without him. He became angry, and his temper escalated to a point where he reportedly broke a window. He begged his wife to stay home and said he would kill himself if she went out. He then went into the bathroom and superficially lacerated the skin on his forearms and inner thighs with a razor blade.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient displays the characteristic features of borderline personality disorder:

• Interpersonal instability and hypersensitivity, including frantic efforts to avoid abandonment (begging his wife to stay home and threatening to kill himself if she leaves)
• Trouble regulating emotions (affective instability), including marked reactivity of mood and inappropriate anger (losing his temper and breaking a window)
• Impulsivity, including suicidal threats or self-mutilating behavior (lacerating his skin)

Patients with borderline personality disorder also typically have an unstable or insecure self-image or sense of self; thus, they fear abandonment and often feel lonely or empty. Although this disorder was historically considered to be more common in women, more recent community-based studies have shown a similar prevalence between men and women.

Key learning point: Borderline personality disorder is characterized by unstable interpersonal relationships, emotional lability or mood instability, impulsivity, and low self-esteem.

B) INCORRECT:

Narcissistic personality disorder involves a pervasive pattern of grandiosity, need for admiration, and lack of empathy. Compared with borderline personality disorder, where self-image is insecure, the grandiose self-image in narcissistic personality disorder is relatively persistent or unchanging. Individuals with narcissistic personality disorder are also less self-destructive, less impulsive, and less worried about being abandoned.

C) INCORRECT:

Antisocial personality disorder involves a pervasive pattern of disregard for, and violation of, the rights of others. In antisocial personality disorder, deceit and manipulation are employed for personal profit or pleasure. In contrast, people with borderline personality disorder manipulate others to seek nurturance. Individuals with antisocial personality disorder tend to be more aggressive and do not exhibit the emotional instability that is typically seen in borderline personality disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Intermittent explosive disorder is characterized by a failure to control aggressive impulses and reactions that are disproportionate to the provocation. However, the outbursts in this condition are not associated with an objective (e.g., coercion), and threats of self-harm and self-mutilating behaviors are not typical features.

E) INCORRECT:

Bipolar disorder involves one or more episodes of abnormally elevated energy level and mood (i.e., a manic episode), with or without depressive episodes.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman with a history of emotional lability, self-injurious behavior, two suicide attempts, and migraines presents to her primary care provider after missing two scheduled appointments. She states that she was too emotionally distraught after her boyfriend ended their relationship to make any of her appointments, including those with her outpatient therapist.
She has an outburst in the clinic, shouting that you are the “worst doctor in the world” for having sent a generic missed-appointment letter rather than a personalized note acknowledging the difficulties she’s facing. She is so upset that she breaks down in tears and wonders aloud whether anyone really cares about her.
Which one of the following statements is the most therapeutic response to this patient?

choices.text: Try to think about how your behavior is affecting others around you. Your outbursts are distressing to everyone in the office.
Let’s talk about the things that are difficult for you right now. I want to hear more about how you’ve been feeling. We can work together to find ways to help you feel better.
I’m not sure why you’re so upset with me. I’m doing my best to care for you and want to be able to help you.
You seem to be really upset right now. It might be a good time to try treatment with a medication to help with your anxiety and help you rest.
I know breakups can be difficult for you and understand how hurt you must feel. Let me arrange for an emergency-department evaluation to make sure that you’re safe.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In the shorter term, the patient is unlikely to be able to accept responsibility for her disruptive behavior. She may perceive any comments about her behavior as unforgiving, scolding, or even vengeful. Anything that makes her feel more vulnerable could make it more difficult for her to control herself. Paradoxically, although she is making critical, angry statements, she may fear being rejected by her health care provider.

B) CORRECT:

Undiagnosed personality disorders are often at the root of the most difficult clinical encounters. Validating a patient’s extreme emotional distress in response to painful circumstances is therapeutic. This approach helps build rapport between the patient and the health care provider and prevents unnecessary visits to the emergency department.

By acknowledging the patient’s distress and offering to listen, the clinician demonstrates a sympathetic attitude that may help the patient regain control and avoid escalating further. In time, once a supportive relationship has been re-established, the patient may accept limits on her conduct in the clinic. She may also gain insight into how her behavior affects others.

Key learning point: In a patient with borderline personality disorder, the most effective short-term therapeutic approach is validation of the patient’s extreme distress and desperation, accompanied by hopeful statements about potential change.

C) INCORRECT:

In the shorter term, the patient is unlikely to be able to accept responsibility for her disruptive behavior. She may perceive any comments about her behavior as unforgiving, scolding, or even vengeful. Anything that makes her feel more vulnerable could make it more difficult for her to control herself. Paradoxically, although she is making critical, angry statements, she may fear being rejected by her health care provider.

D) INCORRECT:

Prescription of an antidepressant or anxiolytic agent should be considered only after a careful history reveals a comorbid depressive or anxiety disorder. In borderline personality disorder, psychosocial treatments (e.g., psychotherapy or social support) are primary, and medications have an adjunctive role. Therefore, patients should be warned to temper their expectations about the benefits of medications.

E) INCORRECT:

Escalating referral to the emergency department is an exaggerated response to the outburst that could cause further regression on the patient’s part.

questions.text:
During her annual health maintenance visit, a 23-year-old single woman with no history of suicide attempts breaks into tears, reporting that she just had an argument with a friend and that she feels betrayed. She reports that this is the third time in 6 months that she has been deeply disappointed by a friend, leaving her feeling empty and as though no one will ever love her. She adamantly denies any suicidal intent. She has cut herself in the past but denies any urge to engage in self-injurious behavior now.
Which one of the following initial therapeutic approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Gently tell her that she is likely exaggerating her symptoms and that the friendship is not in any danger of disrepair
Validate her extreme distress, express hope about potential change, and ask if she would like help with this upsetting pattern
Ask her to step out of the office so that collateral information can be obtained from the friend
Gently offer to prescribe her an antidepressant for her struggles
Refer her to the emergency department for further evaluation and management

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Telling patients that their symptoms are exaggerated or asking for collateral information might feel invalidating and thereby reinforce feelings of worthlessness.

B) CORRECT:

One of the distinctive features of borderline personality disorder is hypersensitivity to rejection and a preoccupation with perceived or expected abandonment. Clinicians can address this issue through a variety of therapeutic approaches, including immediately providing an expression of concern that acknowledges the patient’s distress. Such an empathic statement could foster a therapeutic alliance, soothe the patient, and prevent an unnecessary visit to the emergency department. Given this patient’s observation about the repetitive pattern, it is an appropriate time to raise the possibility of talking to a psychotherapist.

Key learning point: Key approaches to managing a disruptive patient with borderline personality disorder include acknowledging the patient's need for clinician support, validating their extreme distress, and expressing hope about the future.

C) INCORRECT:

Telling patients that their symptoms are exaggerated or asking for collateral information might feel invalidating and thereby reinforce feelings of worthlessness.

D) INCORRECT:

An antidepressant can be considered if a careful history reveals persistent comorbid symptoms of depression. In borderline personality disorder, medications are usually prescribed as an adjunct to core psychosocial treatments. Patients should be advised to temper their expectations regarding the benefits of medication.

E) INCORRECT:

Sending this patient to the emergency department (ED) for further evaluation at this time is not appropriate. Although her risk for self-harm and even suicide over the long-term is greater than that of the general population, the acute risk is low. An ED evaluation could be counterproductive, because it could reinforce regression and may even undermine the patient’s relationship with her primary care provider. Support and encouragement in the office is a better approach because it can help her contain her affect, and it lays the foundation for a referral to psychotherapy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to a counselor at the urging of her parents because they are concerned that she might be depressed. After recently breaking up with her long-term boyfriend, she moved back in with her parents because she could not handle making decisions alone. Soon after their breakup, she started going on 5–7 dates a week. She has been unemployed for 3 years, as her boyfriend took care of all the bills. In the past year, she thought of looking for a job but never felt confident enough to start the process. Her mom arranges her doctor's appointments and handles her car maintenance. She describes feeling uneasy when she is alone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with avoidant personality disorder may also be reluctant to take on personal risks (e.g., apply for new job) because of low self-confidence. However, these patients have difficulty initiating new relationships due to fear of not being liked, and show excessive concern about being criticized. In contrast, this patient seeks out new relationships to compensate for her low self-confidence and is not fearful of rejection or criticism.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with separation anxiety disorder express excessive worry about being alone. However, patients with separation anxiety disorder also exhibit persistent worry about losing an attachment figure, and/or refuse to go away from home without their attachment figure. Also, this disorder disproportionately affects children more so than adults.

C) CORRECT:

This patient demonstrates a pervasive pattern of excessive need to be taken care of that results in dependence on others. She has difficulty making everyday decisions, requires her mother (and previous boyfriend) to assume responsibility for most areas of her life, has difficulty initiating projects (e.g., applying for jobs) due to lack of self-confidence, feels helpless when alone, and urgently seeks new relationships once one fails (e.g., 5–7 dates a week). Based on these findings, she meets the criteria for dependent personality disorder. See “Overview of cluster C personality disorders” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with histrionic personality disorder can be overly theatrical after a failed relationship. However, such patients tend to be attention-seeking, uncomfortable when they are not the center of attention, use physical appearance to draw attention, and/or easily influenced by others.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with borderline personality disorder also excessively seek out interpersonal relationships (e.g., 5–7 dates a week) and fear being alone. However, such patients tend to have unstable relationships, be impulsive, and/or have recurrent suicidal gestures or self-mutilating behavior.
questions.hint: The patient's pervasive pattern of poor self-confidence that manifests as insecurity provides a clue to her diagnosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a fall. After being seen by the triage nurse, he is heard yelling down the hallway, requesting to speak to “whoever is in charge.” He refuses to talk to the emergency resident and insists on talking to the attending physician despite being informed that the attending is currently resuscitating a patient. He says that he deserves better treatment because he has made numerous contributions to the field of medicine. When asked about his work, he mentions that he was a medical device salesman. He is accompanied by his wife, who claims that her husband frequently becomes agitated when his superiority is not recognized and apologizes for her husband's behavior. On mental status examination, the patient is oriented to person, place, and time. There is no disorder of thought process or content. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Individuals with borderline personality disorder may be irritable and exhibit attention-seeking behavior. However, the attention-seeking behavior is usually self-destructive (e.g., self-mutilation) and stems from a fear of rejection or abandonment, rather than an exaggerated sense of self-importance. Moreover, individuals often have marked mood reactivity and an unstable self-image.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with a histrionic personality disorder display attention-seeking behavior. However, attention-seeking behavior is not necessarily associated with a sense of "superiority." Instead, individuals are willing to be viewed as fragile or dependent in order to get attention. They also use physical appearance, flirtatious behavior, and/or theatrical speech to attract attention.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with an intermittent explosive disorder may have recurrent outbursts of verbal aggression, but these outbursts usually begin in childhood and occur much more frequently (≥ 2 times weekly for ≥ 3 months). Moreover, the individual would usually be distressed by his/her own behavior, unlike this individual, who appears self-righteous. Grandiose behavior, a sense of entitlement, and exaggeration of achievements are also not features of intermittent explosive disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with bipolar disorder may exhibit grandiosity and agitation during manic or hypomanic episodes. However, manic or hypomanic episodes are associated with an elevation of mood and other typical symptoms such as an accelerated thought process (“flight of ideas”) and a decreased need for sleep. Moreover, the patient's behavior seems to be consistent over time, which is not consistent with a diagnosis of bipolar disorder.

E) CORRECT:

Narcissistic personality disorder can be diagnosed if ≥ 5 of the following characteristics are pervasive: a grandiose sense of self-importance (as evidenced by exaggeration of achievements or talents); arrogant or haughty behavior; a sense of entitlement; a need for excessive admiration; a need to associate only with people or institutions of the highest status; a tendency to be exploitative (unwittingly or intentionally) in interpersonal relationships; a lack of empathy; envy of others or a belief that others are envious of him/her. This patient has at least 6 of these criteria.

See “Overview of cluster B personality disorders” table.
questions.hint: This man exhibits a grandiose sense of self-importance and a feeling of entitlement. His attempt to interrupt the attending's efforts to save another patient's life also suggests a lack of empathy. He exaggerates his achievements, expects to be recognized as superior, and becomes upset and/or agitated when others fail to acknowledge his superiority. These features also appear to be pervasive, as his wife reports that he has frequently made a scene.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of increasingly withdrawn behavior for the last two years. His mother reports that during this time, her son has spent most of his time in his room playing video games. He does not have any friends and has never had a partner. He usually refuses to attend family dinner and avoids contact with his siblings. The patient states that he prefers being on his own. When his mother starts crying during the visit, he appears indifferent. On mental status examination, his thought process is logical and his affect is flattened. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by constricted affect and a lack of close friends due to acute discomfort in social interactions and impaired capacity for close relationships. However, further symptoms include distortions of perception and cognition (e.g., magical thinking, superstitions), as well as eccentric behavior (e.g., peculiar speech), which are not present in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has signs of social withdrawal, a preference for solitary activities, and flattened affect, all of which are features of schizoid personality disorder. Individuals with schizoid personality disorder neither desire nor enjoy close relationships. They show little interest in interpersonal or sexual contact and often appear indifferent or emotionally cold towards others (see “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table). Of note, the DSM-5 states that personality disorders can be diagnosed in patients < 18 years of age if features have been present for ≥ 1 year. The only exception to this rule is antisocial personality disorder, which can only be diagnosed in patients ≥ 18 years of age.

Personality disorders are characterized by pervasive, inflexible, and maladaptive patterns of relating to and perceiving one's self and one's environment that cause significant distress and/or functional impairment. These patterns typically arise during early adolescence, remain stable over time, and are difficult to treat. Treatment options include psychoeducation, psychotherapy, dialectical behavior therapy, group therapy, and/or cognitive therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by lack of empathy and incapacity for intimacy. However, patients are also prone to deceitful, manipulative, and impulsive behavior and they disregard laws and ethical norms if this provides them personal profit or pleasure. Furthermore, the diagnosis can only be made if the individual is ≥ 18 years of age and there is evidence of conduct disorder prior to 15 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with avoidant personality disorder tend to avoid social interactions, but they do this in spite of a wish to establish social relationships because of extreme anxiety and shyness in social situations brought on by feelings of inadequacy and fear of rejection. This patient does not have an inhibited desire to establish personal relationships.

E) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is characterized by impaired social interaction and communication as well as stereotyped behavior, interests, and activities. Reduced ability for empathy and response in social situations could raise the suspicion of ASD, but symptoms of this disorder are typically recognized in early childhood (2–3 years of age) rather than adolescence.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a rare cluster A personality disorder that has some similarities with the negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the office by his mother because she is worried about his strange behavior. Over the past 3 years, he has been dressing all in black and wears a long black coat, even in the summer. He is anxious at college because he is uncomfortable around other people and he does not have any friends. He spends most of his time reading up on paranormal phenomena, especially demons. He says that sometimes there are signs of their presence, for example, a breeze in an enclosed room is likely the “breath of a demon”. Mental status examination shows laborious speech. The patient avoids eye contact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizoid personality disorder present with eccentric behavior and difficulty developing meaningful social relationships. However, a key component of schizoid personality disorder is a pervasive pattern of social withdrawal and limited range of emotional expression. Patients are content with social isolation and do not seek relationships. Although this patient does not have friends and spends most of his time alone, patients with schizoid personality disorder would be more indifferent about social interactions than anxious. Furthermore, this patient's interest in paranormal phenomena, magical thinking, and eccentric clothing would not be explained by this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with avoidant personality disorder are uncomfortable around other people and avoid social settings. Their discomfort is driven by a feeling of inadequacy and/or an intense fear of rejection or embarrassment, and they tend to desire interpersonal relationships even if they are anxious about interacting with others. However, this patient's social withdrawal appears voluntary and his odd beliefs and unusual clothing choices would not be explained by this diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Schizotypal personality disorder usually manifests with odd and eccentric behavior and appearance. Patients also tend to have odd beliefs or magical thinking that are inconsistent with cultural norms. Moreover, excessive social anxiety, odd speech, inappropriate affect, and lack of close friends are usually also seen.

See “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table.

Key learning point: Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by eccentric behavior, odd beliefs or magical thinking, social anxiety, and lack of close relationships without frank psychosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is usually diagnosed in young children who present with persistent impairment in communication and social interaction as well as restricted, stereotyped patterns of behavior, interests, and activities. Although this young man is uncomfortable around other people, his age and the absence of additional symptoms of ASD, including impaired language skills or repetitive movements and behavior, makes the diagnosis unlikely. The diagnosis of ASD would also not explain this patient's preoccupation with paranormal phenomena.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizophrenia present with chronic and recurrent psychosis for more than 6 months. These patients tend to initially present with a prodrome of negative symptoms characterized by social withdrawal, which is then followed by positive psychotic symptoms (i.e., hallucinations, delusions, and bizarre behaviors). Although this patient prefers to be alone and has odd beliefs, he does not meet the criteria for the diagnosis of schizophrenia, as he has no clear delusions or hallucinations and no disorganized speech.

This patient's laborious speech is not the same as disorganized speech. Laborious speech is nonfluent speech that requires excessive effort and lacks spontaneity, but the thought processes and the contents of the speech are intact. On the other hand, disorganized speech results from disorganized thought processes and can manifest as loose associations (illogical, sudden, and frequent changes of topic), word salad (sequence of words without a logical connection), and flight of ideas (quick succession of thoughts), none of which are evident in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has a cluster A personality disorder.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-day history of difficulty sleeping, which she worries will ruin her career prospects as a model. She has come to the office multiple times for minor problems. She is dressed very extravagantly and flirts with the receptionist. When she is asked to sit down in the waiting room, she begins to cry and says that no one listens to her. When she is called to the examination room, she repeatedly intends to touch the provider's cheek and makes inappropriate comments. She does not have a history of self-harm or suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with a dependent personality disorder may visit their provider frequently because they seek support and reassurance. However, they typically behave timidly and politely rather than flirtatiously and flamboyantly. In addition, patients with dependent personality disorder tend to have difficulty making everyday decisions and often require others to take over responsibilities for them, none of which is seen here.

B) CORRECT:

Histrionic personality disorder is characterized by excessive emotionality and attention-seeking behavior. According to DSM-5, a diagnosis of histrionic personality disorder can be made in patients with ≥ 5 of the following 8 criteria: inappropriate seductive behavior, the use of physical appearance to draw attention to oneself, discomfort when the individual is not the center of attention, emotional lability, theatricality, considering relationships to be more intimate than they actually are, impressionistic speech, and suggestibility (i.e., being easily influenced by others). This patient meets the first 6 criteria.

See “Overview of cluster B personality disorders” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with narcissistic personality disorder may exhibit attention-seeking behavior and exaggerate the intimacy of their relationships with others. However, this attention-seeking behavior stems from a desire for praise and admiration rather than from a need for reassurance or approval. Patients with narcissistic personality disorder are more likely to react to criticism or rejection with rage rather than the emotional vulnerability seen here (e.g., crying). In addition, they exhibit other traits not seen in this patient, such as an excessive sense of self-importance, exaggeration of achievements, grandiosity, arrogance, a lack of empathy, and envy.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder may dress and behave eccentrically. However, they do not typically use physical appearance for the purpose of garnering attention. In addition, individuals with schizotypal personality disorder often display an impaired capacity and discomfort with close personal contact, rather than the excessive intimacy and flirtatiousness seen here. Moreover, they typically have superstitious beliefs and/or magical thinking.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with borderline personality disorder may exhibit attention-seeking or manipulative behavior, rapidly shifting emotions, intense interpersonal relationships that alternate between extreme idealization and extreme devaluation, and a fear of abandonment. However, essential components of borderline personality disorder are a negative self-image and self-destructive behavior (e.g., self-harm, suicide attempts), which this patient does not have.
questions.hint: The patient has a personality disorder that has features that include inappropriately seductive behavior (e.g., flirting with the receptionist, inappropriate contact with the provider), emotional instability (e.g., shifting from flirting to crying and back to flirting), using her physical appearance to draw attention to herself (e.g., dressing extravagantly), and becoming uncomfortable when she is not the center of attention (e.g., coming to the office for multiple minor problems, claiming that no one listens to her).

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the office because of nervousness and difficulty sleeping over the past 2 weeks. Three months ago, he started a new team project at his job and has trouble falling asleep at night because he thinks about the project. He insists on checking the work of his teammates and spends several hours each week making elaborate lists and schedules. He says, “My teammates never understand how important it is to do things the right way.” The project deadline has already been postponed once. Ever since high school, he has used the majority of his time to plan out assignments and does not have time to regularly participate in social activities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder (OCPD) is a personality disorder characterized by inflexibility, excessive perfectionism, and preoccupation with order and control. Patients with OCPD often make lists and schedules to an extent that the main details of a task or activity are lost; their perfectionism interferes with task completion and social relationships. Therapeutic options for OCPD include cognitive behavioral therapy, psychodynamic psychotherapy, relaxation, and supplemental treatment with antidepressants. However, treatment is difficult because this personality disorder is egosyntonic.

See “Overview of cluster C personality disorders” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Obsessive-compulsive disorder manifests with recurrent worries that cause distress and insomnia. However, patients with OCD typically have very intrusive and time-consuming thoughts, images, or urges and show repetitive behaviors that are performed in response to these intrusions. Additionally, OCD is characteristically egodystonic; there is no indication that this man views his behavior as inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Specific phobias are characterized by persistent and intense fear and/or anxiety due to a specific situation or object. This patient has anxiety better explained by another diagnosis and does not express fear of his stressors. Additionally, specific phobias can only be diagnosed if symptoms have been present for ≥ 6 months.

D) INCORRECT:

Generalized anxiety disorder can manifest with recurrent worrying and insomnia. However, it usually involves severe anxiety caused by various aspects of daily life and significant social or occupational impairment; this patient is primarily worried about an upcoming project rather than multiple facets of life. Additionally, GAD can only be diagnosed if symptoms have been present for ≥ 6 months.

E) INCORRECT:

Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by limited emotional expression and voluntary social withdrawal. There is no evidence of limited emotional range in this patient and he does not participate in social activities because of lack of time.
questions.hint: This man's beliefs are egosyntonic (i.e., he views his perceptions and behavior as reasonable and appropriate).

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. She reports that she has argued with her husband a lot recently because she suspects that he is cheating on her. She hasn't spoken to her sister in 4 years because her sister “always humiliates me in front of others.” She gets along well with her friends but does not talk to them about her problems because she is afraid they will gossip about her behind her back. She has been monogamous with her husband for the entire marriage except for a sexual relationship with a colleague 13 months ago. She has a neutral affect and her speech is normal. Her thought content focuses on possible negative eventualities, but she demonstrates intact reality testing. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by excessive suspicion and pervasive distrust of others, while psychotic symptoms are absent. Individuals with paranoid personality disorder often present with suspicions of infidelity, unjustified fear that others will use information against them, and disproportionate reactions to perceived attacks. Consequently, individuals with paranoid personality disorder tend to be emotionally isolated and unable to form close interpersonal relationships (See “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table).

Most patients with personality disorders consider their symptoms normal; these egosyntonic behavioral traits lead to significant distress and impaired social functioning. Personality disorders typically begin in early adulthood and remain stable over time. Treatment is challenging and usually includes psychotherapy. Symptomatic treatment may be helpful in patients with comorbid traits (e.g., symptoms of anxiety, psychosis).

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with schizoid personality disorder may be unable to form close interpersonal relationships and find it difficult to trust others. However, schizoid personality disorder typically also manifests with little interest in sexual relationships and a preference for solitary activities, and mental status examination may show flattened affect.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with avoidant personality disorder refrain from interpersonal contact because of a preoccupation with, and hypersensitivity to, criticism. However, in avoidant personality disorder, the lack of interpersonal contact results from feelings of inadequacy, low self-esteem, and risk avoidance rather than distrust of others.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder may be suspicious and distrustful of others and often lack close friends. However, schizotypal personality disorder typically also manifests with eccentric behavior (e.g., bizarre speech) or physical appearance, magical thinking, unusual perceptual experiences (e.g., body illusions), and/or constricted affect, none of which is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with delusional disorder may have an exaggerated distrust of others and insist that they are being cheated on, conspired against, and/or harassed. However, delusional disorder also manifests with at least one type of delusion (e.g., jealous, erotomanic, grandiose) and associated clinical features. While individuals with delusional disorder may show impaired reality testing and/or abnormalities of thought content regarding the delusional belief, functioning unrelated to the belief is typically normal.
questions.hint: Projection is a defense mechanism often seen in individuals with this condition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents after an argument with his wife. He reports that his mood was fine until she told him that she was going to dinner with some friends without him. He became angry, and his temper escalated to a point where he reportedly broke a window. He begged his wife to stay home and said he would kill himself if she went out. He then went into the bathroom and superficially lacerated the skin on his forearms and inner thighs with a razor blade. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient displays the characteristic features of borderline personality disorder:

• Interpersonal instability and hypersensitivity, including frantic efforts to avoid abandonment (begging his wife to stay home and threatening to kill himself if she leaves)
• Trouble regulating emotions (affective instability), including marked reactivity of mood and inappropriate anger (losing his temper and breaking a window)
• Impulsivity, including suicidal threats or self-mutilating behavior (lacerating his skin)

Although this disorder was historically considered to be more common in women, more recent community-based studies have shown a similar prevalence between men and women.

Key learning point: Borderline personality disorder is characterized by unstable interpersonal relationships, emotional lability or mood instability, impulsivity, and low self-esteem.

B) INCORRECT:

Narcissistic personality disorder involves a pervasive pattern of grandiosity, need for admiration, and lack of empathy. Compared with this patient, whose self-image is insecure, the grandiose self-image in narcissistic personality disorder is relatively persistent or unchanging. Individuals with narcissistic personality disorder are also less self-destructive, less impulsive, and less worried about being abandoned.

C) INCORRECT:

Antisocial personality disorder involves a pervasive pattern of disregard for, and violation of, the rights of others. In antisocial personality disorder, deceit and manipulation are employed for personal profit or pleasure. In contrast, people with this patient's disorder manipulate others to seek nurturance. Individuals with antisocial personality disorder tend to be more aggressive and do not exhibit the emotional instability that is seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Intermittent explosive disorder is characterized by a failure to control aggressive impulses and reactions that are disproportionate to the provocation. However, the outbursts in this condition are not associated with an objective (e.g., coercion), and threats of self-harm and self-mutilating behaviors are not typical features.

E) INCORRECT:

Bipolar disorder involves one or more episodes of abnormally elevated energy level and mood (i.e., a manic episode), with or without depressive episodes.
questions.hint: Patients with this disorder also typically have an unstable or insecure self-image or sense of self; thus, they fear abandonment and often feel lonely or empty.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college sophomore comes to the student clinic for an annual physical examination. During the visit, she admits to having only two friends on campus, which she attributes to being shy, which she says has been the case for as long as she can remember. She intentionally enrolls in classes that do not require participation for fear of being criticized. She works as a library shelver and has turned down promotions for a front desk position because she is afraid her coworkers will not like her. The patient turns down invitations to parties to avoid being rejected by new people. She worries that she may not be able to find a boyfriend who thinks she is good enough. The patient most likely has which of the following primary diagnoses?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient demonstrates a pervasive pattern of avoidance of occupational activities that involve interpersonal contact, preoccupation with criticism and rejection, unwillingness to start new intimate relationships, and inhibition in new interpersonal situations while retaining a desire to form relationships with others. These behavioral patterns have been present since adolescence and impair her social functioning in various contexts. Based on these findings, she meets the criteria for avoidant personality disorder. See “Overview of cluster C personality disorders” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizoid personality disorder usually have few interpersonal relationships and choose solitary activities. However, these patients do not desire close relationships and are indifferent to the criticism of others.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with generalized anxiety disorder may exhibit fear and anxiety in social settings. However, patients with this condition typically have excessive anxiety and/or worry about several aspects of daily life (e.g., work, finances, family) in addition to symptoms of restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, muscle tension, and/or sleep disturbances. This patient lacks these symptoms. In addition, this patient's intense fear of criticism from others and a desire for interpersonal relationships are more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with shyness may feel awkward or apprehensive about being in close proximity to other people. However, this patient's symptoms impair her daily functioning (e.g., turning down a front desk job, minimal interpersonal relationships), which indicates her behavior is more severe than normal shyness.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with performance anxiety may have fears and/or anxiety about taking a class in which they would be called upon to answer a question. However, this patient's anxiety extends beyond just performing an activity, as she is anxious about several different social situations that are unrelated to performance (e.g., going to parties) and has feelings of inadequacy and low self-esteem that suggest another diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient demonstrates an enduring, inflexible, and maladaptive pattern of behavior that impairs her functioning.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with multiple visits for self-inflicted cuts on her arms after conflicts with her romantic partner. She has had numerous relationships lasting only a few months, marked by intense arguments and frantic efforts to avoid being alone. She describes feeling empty and oscillates between idealizing and devaluing her partners. Physical examination reveals multiple superficial lacerations in the process of healing.
Which of the following best explains her condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bipolar II disorder involves distinct hypomanic episodes and major depression, neither of which is evident here. The patient's chronic patterns of unstable relationships, fear of abandonment, and impulsive self-harm suggest emotional dysregulation, not the episodic mood changes of bipolar II disorder. Her symptoms indicate enduring relationship instability and identity disturbance rather than discrete mood episodes.

B) CORRECT:

Borderline personality disorder manifests with pervasive instability in interpersonal relationships, self-image, and affect, along with marked impulsivity. The patient's self-injurious behavior, particularly in response to perceived abandonment, reflects the emotional dysregulation characteristic of this disorder. Additionally, the pattern of alternating idealization and devaluation of partners indicates identity disturbance and unstable interpersonal conduct. These features, combined with recurrent cutting and turbulent relationships, encapsulate the core psychopathological aspects of borderline personality disorder.

Key learning point: Borderline Personality Disorder is characterized by unstable interpersonal relationships, self-image, and emotions, impulsive behaviors, and fear of abandonment, often leading to self-harm and mood variability.

C) INCORRECT:

Histrionic personality disorder is marked by excessive emotionality and a need for attention, often through dramatic behaviors. However, it does not typically involve self-injurious actions or intense fear of abandonment. The patient's self-harm, unstable relationships, and feelings of emptiness align more with borderline personality disorder than histrionic personality disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Major depressive disorder requires a sustained period of depressed mood or anhedonia, along with symptoms like sleep disturbances and feelings of worthlessness. While self-harm can occur in depression, the absence of pervasive depressed mood and neurovegetative symptoms in this patient suggests a different diagnosis. Her behavior aligns more with interpersonal instability and impulsivity rather than a persistent depressive state.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his mother because of increasingly withdrawn behavior over the past two years. His mother reports that he spends most of his time in his room playing video games, does not have any friends, and has never had a partner. He usually refuses to attend family dinners and avoids contact with his siblings. The patient tells you he prefers being alone. When his mother becomes tearful during the visit, he appears indifferent. On mental status examination, his thought process is logical and his affect is flattened. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is characterized by impaired social interaction and communication as well as stereotyped behavior, interests, and activities. Reduced ability for empathy and response in social situations could raise the suspicion of ASD, but symptoms of this disorder are typically recognized in early childhood (2–3 years of age) rather than adolescence.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with avoidant personality disorder tend to avoid social interactions, but they do this in spite of a wish to establish social relationships because of extreme anxiety and shyness in social situations brought on by feelings of inadequacy and fear of rejection. This patient does not have an inhibited desire to establish personal relationships.

C) INCORRECT:

Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by lack of empathy and incapacity for intimacy. However, patients are also prone to deceitful, manipulative, and impulsive behavior and they disregard laws and ethical norms if this provides them personal profit or pleasure. Furthermore, the diagnosis can only be made if the individual is ≥ 18 years of age and there is evidence of conduct disorder prior to 15 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by constricted affect and a lack of close friends due to acute discomfort in social interactions and impaired capacity for close relationships. However, further symptoms include distortions of perception and cognition (e.g., magical thinking, superstitions), as well as eccentric behavior (e.g., peculiar speech), which are not present in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has signs of social withdrawal, a preference for solitary activities, and flattened affect, all of which are features of schizoid personality disorder. Individuals with schizoid personality disorder neither desire nor enjoy close relationships. They show little interest in interpersonal or sexual contact and often appear indifferent or emotionally cold towards others (see “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table). Of note, the DSM-5 states that personality disorders can be diagnosed in patients < 18 years of age if features have been present for ≥ 1 year. The only exception to this rule is antisocial personality disorder, which can only be diagnosed in patients ≥ 18 years of age.

Personality disorders are characterized by pervasive, inflexible, and maladaptive patterns of relating to and perceiving one's self and one's environment that cause significant distress and/or functional impairment. These patterns typically arise during early adolescence, remain stable over time, and are difficult to treat. Treatment options include psychoeducation, psychotherapy, dialectical behavior therapy, group therapy, and/or cognitive therapy.

Key learning point: Schizoid personality disorder is marked by social detachment, preference for solitary activities, emotional coldness, and lack of desire for close relationships.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a rare cluster A personality disorder that has some similarities with the negative symptoms of schizophrenia.

questions.text: You are seeing a 19-year-old man who is brought to your clinic by his mother due to concerns about his unusual behavior. Over the past 3 years, he has been dressing entirely in black and wears a long black coat, even during the summer. He reports feeling anxious at college because he is uncomfortable around other people and does not have any friends. He spends most of his time reading about paranormal phenomena, particularly demons. He describes sometimes noticing signs of their presence, such as interpreting a breeze in an enclosed room as the “breath of a demon.” On mental status examination, his speech is slow and effortful, and he avoids eye contact. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizophrenia present with chronic and recurrent psychosis for more than 6 months. These patients tend to initially present with a prodrome of negative symptoms characterized by social withdrawal, which is then followed by positive psychotic symptoms (i.e., hallucinations, delusions, and bizarre behaviors). Although this patient prefers to be alone and has odd beliefs, he does not meet the criteria for the diagnosis of schizophrenia, as he has no clear delusions or hallucinations and no disorganized speech.

This patient's laborious speech is not the same as disorganized speech. Laborious speech is nonfluent speech that requires excessive effort and lacks spontaneity, but the thought processes and the contents of the speech are intact. On the other hand, disorganized speech results from disorganized thought processes and can manifest as loose associations (illogical, sudden, and frequent changes of topic), word salad (sequence of words without a logical connection), and flight of ideas (quick succession of thoughts), none of which are evident in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is usually diagnosed in young children who present with persistent impairment in communication and social interaction as well as restricted, stereotyped patterns of behavior, interests, and activities. Although this young man is uncomfortable around other people, his age and the absence of additional symptoms of ASD, including impaired language skills or repetitive movements and behavior, makes the diagnosis unlikely. The diagnosis of ASD would also not explain this patient's preoccupation with paranormal phenomena.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizoid personality disorder present with eccentric behavior and difficulty developing meaningful social relationships. However, a key component of schizoid personality disorder is a pervasive pattern of social withdrawal and limited range of emotional expression. Patients are content with social isolation and do not seek relationships. Although this patient does not have friends and spends most of his time alone, patients with schizoid personality disorder would be more indifferent about social interactions than anxious. Furthermore, this patient's interest in paranormal phenomena, magical thinking, and eccentric clothing would not be explained by this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with avoidant personality disorder are uncomfortable around other people and avoid social settings. Their discomfort is driven by a feeling of inadequacy and/or an intense fear of rejection or embarrassment, and they tend to desire interpersonal relationships even if they are anxious about interacting with others. However, this patient's social withdrawal appears voluntary and his odd beliefs and unusual clothing choices would not be explained by this diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Schizotypal personality disorder usually manifests with odd and eccentric behavior and appearance. Patients also tend to have odd beliefs or magical thinking that are inconsistent with cultural norms. Moreover, excessive social anxiety, odd speech, inappropriate affect, and lack of close friends are usually also seen.

See “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table.

Key learning point: Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by eccentric behavior, odd beliefs or magical thinking, social anxiety, and lack of close relationships without frank psychosis.
questions.hint: This patient has a cluster A personality disorder.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-day history of difficulty sleeping. She expresses concern that this will negatively affect her career prospects as a model. She has visited your clinic multiple times for minor concerns. She is dressed in an extravagant manner and is flirtatious with the receptionist. When asked to wait, she becomes tearful and says that no one listens to her. In the examination room, she repeatedly tries to touch your cheek and makes inappropriate comments. She does not have a history of self-harm or suicidal ideation. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Histrionic personality disorder is characterized by excessive emotionality and attention-seeking behavior. According to DSM-5, a diagnosis of histrionic personality disorder can be made in patients with ≥ 5 of the following 8 criteria: inappropriate seductive behavior, the use of physical appearance to draw attention to oneself, discomfort when the individual is not the center of attention, emotional lability, theatricality, considering relationships to be more intimate than they actually are, impressionistic speech, and suggestibility (i.e., being easily influenced by others). This patient meets the first 6 criteria.

See “Overview of cluster B personality disorders” table.

Key learning point: Histrionic personality disorder is marked by excessive emotionality, attention-seeking, inappropriate seductiveness, and discomfort when not the center of attention.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder may dress and behave eccentrically. However, they do not typically use physical appearance for the purpose of garnering attention. In addition, individuals with schizotypal personality disorder often display an impaired capacity and discomfort with close personal contact, rather than the excessive intimacy and flirtatiousness seen here. Moreover, they typically have superstitious beliefs and/or magical thinking.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with borderline personality disorder may exhibit attention-seeking or manipulative behavior, rapidly shifting emotions, intense interpersonal relationships that alternate between extreme idealization and extreme devaluation, and a fear of abandonment. However, essential components of borderline personality disorder are a negative self-image and self-destructive behavior (e.g., self-harm, suicide attempts), which this patient does not have.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with narcissistic personality disorder may exhibit attention-seeking behavior and exaggerate the intimacy of their relationships with others. However, this attention-seeking behavior stems from a desire for praise and admiration rather than from a need for reassurance or approval. Patients with narcissistic personality disorder are more likely to react to criticism or rejection with rage rather than the emotional vulnerability seen here (e.g., crying). In addition, they exhibit other traits not seen in this patient, such as an excessive sense of self-importance, exaggeration of achievements, grandiosity, arrogance, a lack of empathy, and envy.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with a dependent personality disorder may visit their provider frequently because they seek support and reassurance. However, they typically behave timidly and politely rather than flirtatiously and flamboyantly. In addition, patients with dependent personality disorder tend to have difficulty making everyday decisions and often require others to take over responsibilities for them, none of which is seen here.
questions.hint: The patient has a personality disorder that has features that include inappropriately seductive behavior (e.g., flirting with the receptionist, inappropriate contact with the provider), emotional instability (e.g., shifting from flirting to crying and back to flirting), using her physical appearance to draw attention to herself (e.g., dressing extravagantly), and becoming uncomfortable when she is not the center of attention (e.g., coming to the office for multiple minor problems, claiming that no one listens to her).

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to your clinic for an annual physical examination. She works part-time in a supermarket stockroom and recently declined an offer to work as a cashier for higher pay because she is afraid customers will not like her. She does not attend her college classes due to fear of being criticized during group discussions. She has one close childhood friend and avoids attending parties she is invited to. She wishes she had more friends but feels she is not good enough for them. She reports having similar difficulties during high school. Which one of the following best describes her behavior?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with social anxiety disorder have marked anxiety about one or more social situations to the extent that they may also avoid certain social settings, which may affect occupational functioning and interpersonal relationships. However, this patient's broad avoidance of social settings combined with an intense fear of criticism of others and a desire for further interpersonal relationships is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with generalized anxiety disorder may exhibit fear and anxiety in social settings. However, patients with this condition typically have excessive anxiety and/or worry about several events (e.g., work, finances) in addition to symptoms of restlessness, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, irritability, muscle tension, and/or sleep disturbances. This patient lacks these symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with shyness may feel awkward or apprehensive when in close proximity to other people. However, this patient's shyness significantly impairs her daily functioning (e.g., turning down a cashier job, minimal interpersonal relationships), which indicates that her behavior is pathologic and more severe than normal shyness.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with schizoid personality disorder usually have few interpersonal relationships and choose solitary activities. However, these patients do not desire close relationships and are indifferent to the criticism of others. This patient would like more friends and is hypersensitive to criticism and acceptance from others, which suggests another diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient demonstrates a pervasive pattern of avoidance of occupational activities that involve interpersonal contact (e.g., cashier job), preoccupation with criticism (e.g., avoiding classes because of fears of critique), restraint with intimate relationships (e.g., only one friend), and inhibition in new interpersonal situations (e.g., turning down invitations to parties) that has been present since adolescence and impairs her social functioning in various contexts (e.g., school, work, friends). Based on these behaviors, she meets the criteria for avoidant personality disorder. Patients with this condition have a strong desire for social relationships (unlike schizoid personality disorder) but are limited by extreme shyness and social anxiety.

Key learning point: Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by social inhibition, hypersensitivity to criticism, feelings of inadequacy, and a strong desire for relationships despite pervasive avoidance of social interactions.
questions.hint: This patient demonstrates an enduring, inflexible, and maladaptive pattern of behavior that impairs her functioning.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to your clinic after an argument with his wife. He reports that his mood was stable until his wife told him she was going to dinner with friends without him. He became angry, and his temper escalated to the point where he broke a window. He begged his wife to stay home and threatened to kill himself if she went out. He then went into the bathroom and superficially lacerated the skin on his forearms and inner thighs with a razor blade. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Narcissistic personality disorder involves a pervasive pattern of grandiosity, need for admiration, and lack of empathy. Compared with this patient, whose self-image is insecure, the grandiose self-image in narcissistic personality disorder is relatively persistent or unchanging. Individuals with narcissistic personality disorder are also less self-destructive, less impulsive, and less worried about being abandoned.

B) INCORRECT:

Intermittent explosive disorder is characterized by a failure to control aggressive impulses and reactions that are disproportionate to the provocation. However, the outbursts in this condition are not associated with an objective (e.g., coercion), and threats of self-harm and self-mutilating behaviors are not typical features.

C) INCORRECT:

Bipolar disorder involves one or more episodes of abnormally elevated energy level and mood (i.e., a manic episode), with or without depressive episodes.

D) CORRECT:

This patient displays the characteristic features of borderline personality disorder:

• Interpersonal instability and hypersensitivity, including frantic efforts to avoid abandonment (begging his wife to stay home and threatening to kill himself if she leaves)
• Trouble regulating emotions (affective instability), including marked reactivity of mood and inappropriate anger (losing his temper and breaking a window)
• Impulsivity, including suicidal threats or self-mutilating behavior (lacerating his skin)

Although this disorder was historically considered to be more common in women, more recent community-based studies have shown a similar prevalence between men and women.

Key learning point: Borderline personality disorder is characterized by unstable interpersonal relationships, emotional lability or mood instability, impulsivity, and low self-esteem.

E) INCORRECT:

Antisocial personality disorder involves a pervasive pattern of disregard for, and violation of, the rights of others. In antisocial personality disorder, deceit and manipulation are employed for personal profit or pleasure. In contrast, people with this patient's disorder manipulate others to seek nurturance. Individuals with antisocial personality disorder tend to be more aggressive and do not exhibit the emotional instability that is seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Patients with this disorder also typically have an unstable or insecure self-image or sense of self; thus, they fear abandonment and often feel lonely or empty.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with superficial lacerations on her forearms after an argument with her boyfriend. She reports cutting herself “to feel something” and denies suicidal ideation. During the interview, she alternates between praising staff and becoming hostile when left alone. She has multiple previous ED visits for similar presentations and states she fears being abandoned. Her vital signs are normal and she appears alert and oriented. What is the most appropriate disposition for this patient?

choices.text: Observation until psychiatric evaluation is complete
Discharge with anxiolytic prescription and primary care follow-up
Discharge with wound care instructions only
Discharge with outpatient psychiatry follow-up and safety planning

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prolonged observation is not indicated if the patient is medically stable and denies suicidal ideation. This approach may reinforce attention-seeking behaviors and does not address the underlying need for structured outpatient care.

B) INCORRECT:

Psychiatric hospitalization is not automatically indicated for nonsuicidal self-injury in personality disorders. This patient denies suicidal ideation and appears stable, making involuntary hospitalization inappropriate and potentially harmful by reinforcing maladaptive coping patterns.

C) INCORRECT:

Prescribing anxiolytics for symptom relief in personality disorders is inappropriate and may encourage dependency on acute care services. Medication should only be used to facilitate immediate care, not as symptomatic treatment for personality disorders.

D) INCORRECT:

Focusing solely on wound care ignores the underlying psychiatric presentation and is inadequate care. Patients with personality disorders require appropriate psychiatric follow-up and safety planning to prevent future presentations.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has features consistent with borderline personality disorder, including fear of abandonment, unstable relationships, and nonsuicidal self-injury. Since she denies suicidal ideation and appears stable, discharge with appropriate follow-up and safety planning is most appropriate. Distinguishing nonsuicidal self-injury from suicidal behavior is key to avoiding unnecessary hospitalizations.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient with borderline personality disorder presents to the emergency department following an argument with their roommate. The patient has superficial forearm lacerations and reports feeling “empty and abandoned.” They oscillate between tearful pleas for help and angry outbursts, stating “Nobody understands me” and “I just want to leave.” The patient interrupts the interview frequently and becomes increasingly agitated when discussing the evaluation timeline. What is the most appropriate initial strategy to optimize the therapeutic encounter and facilitate an accurate risk assessment?

choices.text: Establish clear behavioral expectations while acknowledging the patient's emotional distress
Administer anxiolytic medication to reduce agitation before proceeding with the interview
Request security presence to ensure staff safety during the evaluation
Focus primarily on medical clearance and arrange immediate psychiatric consultation
Limit interview time to prevent further escalation and expedite disposition

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Setting expectations regarding time limits, interruptions, and behavior while validating the patient's concerns and emotions are key strategies for productive encounters. This dual approach addresses both the behavioral challenges and emotional distress, facilitating the therapeutic relationship necessary to make an accurate suicide risk assessment.

B) INCORRECT:

Medication should only be prescribed as needed to facilitate care, not purely for symptom relief. Therapeutic communication strategies should be attempted first, and medication should not be presented as treatment for personality disorders or used to encourage repeat visits.

C) INCORRECT:

Having security staff present is not recommended as an initial approach and could undermine the therapeutic relationship. Deescalation techniques and effective communication are primary strategies, with security reserved for situations in which nonpharmacological interventions have been unsuccessful.

D) INCORRECT:

Psychiatric consultation may be appropriate, but rushing through the evaluation without establishing proper therapeutic communication compromises the ability to accurately assess the suicide risk and provide appropriate crisis intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

Limiting the interview time prevents making an adequate risk assessment and makes it difficult to accurately evaluate the suicide risk and potential for self-harm. A thorough evaluation is important, not an expedited disposition.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual physical examination. She works part-time at a supermarket in the stockroom and recently turned down an offer to work as a cashier for more money because she is afraid the customers will not like her. She does not attend her college classes because she is afraid others will criticize her during group discussions. The patient has one close childhood friend and avoids parties to which she is invited. She would like more friends but thinks she is not good enough for them. She had similar problems during high school. Which of the following best describes this patient's behavior?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with shyness may feel awkward or apprehensive when in close proximity to other people. However, this patient's shyness significantly impairs her daily functioning (e.g., turning down a cashier job, minimal interpersonal relationships), which indicates that her behavior is pathologic and more severe than normal shyness.

B) CORRECT:

This patient demonstrates a pervasive pattern of avoidance of occupational activities that involve interpersonal contact (e.g., cashier job), preoccupation with criticism (e.g., avoiding classes because of fears of critique), restraint with intimate relationships (e.g., only one friend), and inhibition in new interpersonal situations (e.g., turning down invitations to parties) that has been present since adolescence and impairs her social functioning in various contexts (e.g., school, work, friends).
